Description.val:
This budget line item includes various procurements such as engineering efforts, engineering change proposals, modifications, and other related items less than $5 million each.

Corrosion Prevention and Control (CPAC) Program provides a comprehensive approach to extend the useful life on Marine Corps tactical ground and ground support equipment. The CPAC Program Office is responsible for the governance, oversight and management of both preventive and corrective corrosion control encompassing Acquisition Engineering, Material Development, Corrosion Service Teams, and Corrosion Repair Facility activities.  The Consolidated CPAC Program provides a total lifecycle solution focused on Total Ownership Cost reduction and improved readiness.

Engineer Mods and Tool Kits funds critical improvements to various pieces of equipment by enhancing their current capabilities and expanding protection from direct and indirect fire by providing specific tool kits, including the specific chest or case to store and transport the tools, to perform specific missions assigned to engineer units, such as carpentry, grubbing or clearing areas with pioneer type tools, destruction/demolition, masonry, electrical (base camp support), plumbing, etc. including (but not limited to) Construction Shop Kit, Pioneer Platoon Kit, Pioneer Squad Kit, Carpenter Kit, Mason Kit, and tactical weld shop upgrades.

Marine Corps Family of Containers (MCFC) provides Marine Corps Operating Forces with a fully intermodal transport capability emphasizing dimensional standardization and International Organization for Standardization compatibility. This family of containers includes the Palletized Container (PALCON), Quadruple Container (QUADCON), Quadruple Container with Roll-up door (QUADCON RUD) and Joint Modular Intermodal Container  (JMIC). PALCONs and JMICs replace prefabricated wooden mount boxes and flat box pallets.  The Joint Modular Intermodal Container (JMIC) provides efficient, seamless, and visible movement of supplies and unit equipment throughout the transportation and distribution systems. All containers support the storage and movement of organizational property and consumable supplies; provide field, garrison and shipboard warehousing; and facilitate ship-to-shore movement.

Family of Expeditionary Water Systems (FEWS) is a family of systems line that contains purification, storage, distribution, hygiene, and test systems. This capability is necessary to provide safe and potable water to Marines in expeditionary environments. The family contains individual Table of Allowance Material Control Numbers which supports MAGTF operations by providing all aspects of land-based water support to include analysis, purification, reuse, storage, transfer and dispensing. The line contains items such as the Tactical Water Purification System (TWPS), Lightweight Water Purification System (LWPS), Expeditionary Water Distribution System (EWDS), Platoon Water Purification System (PWPS), Individual Water Purification System (IWPS), Forward Area Water Point Supply System, Pump Unit Set, Containerized Batch Laundry, Shower Systems, Gray Water Recycling, as well as all the various water supply support and analysis components and equipment including Six Container (SIXCON) Pump and Tank Modules, Nozzles, Interconnection Sets, Water Packaging Components, 3k/5k/25k Tanks, Hypocholorination Units, Water Quality Analysis Sets.

Justification.val:
FY 2019: $13.711M (Active: $13.201M/Reserve: $0.510M)

Corrosion Prevention and Control (CPAC) $0.885M: The consolidated CPAC program currently monitors the corrosion condition of 112,672 tactical ground and support equipment assets.  FY19 funding continues to procure equipment protective covers designed to reduce and/or eliminate the negative effects of corrosion on USMC ground tactical and support equipment and the replacement of aging covers that have exceeded their life expectancy.  The priority will be to provide equipment covers throughout the Operating Forces for equipment placed in an administrative staging program to mitigate the negative impacts of corrosion and decrease total ownership costs.  Procurement funding is also used for the fielding and replacement of various personal property/collateral equipment, and highly specialized real property installed equipment such as, but not limited to, compressors, blast booths, aging sanding and painting related equipment and hazardous waste reduction equipment at the Corrosion Repair Facilities (CRFs) located at I Marine Expeditionary Force, (I MEF), II MEF, and III MEF (Okinawa and Hawaii).

Engineer Modification Kits (EMK) $7.476M (Active: $7.297M/Reserve: $0.179M): Additional funding provides upgrades to Modified-Full Width Mine Plows (M-FWMP), Field Service Representative (FSR) support and Tech Manual updates for the Assault Breacher Vehicle (ABV).  Funds Improved Ribbon Bridge (IRB) Hinge modernization kit increasing the Reliability, Availability, and Maintainability (RAM) lowering future sustainment costs.  Funds the Husky and Husky Mounted Detection System FSRs and the Instrument Set, Reconnaissance & Surveying Army system to maintain the Authority to Operate and keep pace with the Army system configuration.  Continues to fund EMK for equipment armor installations, upgrades and safety concerns to prevent deterioration in Fleet readiness for Engineer Systems inventory consisting of over 47,000 end items associated to 120 Table of Authorized Material Control Numbers (TAMCNs).  Supports modifications and upgrades to fielded legacy as well as newly fielded systems and provides quick response capability for meeting Fleet Marine Force sustainment for safety engineering, readiness, Quality Deficiency Report analysis, and legacy system modifications.  Funds Expeditionary Mobile Fuel Additization Capability (EMFAC) due to an Urgent Universal Needs Statement and Cooling and Refrigeration Expeditionary Kits (CREK) Foam Kit Assembly efforts.  

Marine Corps Family of Containers (MCFC) $1.087M: Funds Joint Modular Intermodal Containers (JMIC). The JMIC is a collapsible, durable, reusable, easy-to-handle, modular packaging container that can operate world-wide, carried by various modes of transportation, and is envisioned for future use as a compliment to Navy seabasing efforts for automatic loading, handling, and storage systems. The JMIC will enable Marines to fulfill their mission by giving the unit commander the flexibility to configure a mobile/deployable container as necessary to meet the specific mission of the unit. It provides the operating forces with a fully intermodal transport capability which lays flat when not in use. The JMIC also provides a more effective use of storage areas in particularly limited storage facilities. Funding is required to meet the Approved Acquisition Objective outlined in the Total Force Structure Management System. 

Family of Expeditionary Water Systems (FEWS) $4.263M (Active: $3.932M/Reserve: $0.331M): Funds procure PWPS and supports the procurement of a critically needed ECP for the M80 Water Heater.  

FY 2020: $10.956M (Active: $10.585M/Reserve: $0.371M)

Corrosion Prevention and Control (CPAC) $0.895M: The consolidated CPAC program currently monitors the corrosion condition of 112,672 tactical ground and support equipment assets.  FY20 funding continues to procure equipment protective covers designed to reduce and/or eliminate the negative effects of corrosion on USMC ground tactical and support equipment and the replacement of aging covers that have exceeded their life expectancy.  The priority will be to provide equipment covers throughout the Operating Forces for equipment placed in an administrative staging program to mitigate the negative impacts of corrosion and decrease total ownership costs.  Procurement funding is also used for the fielding and replacement of various personal property/collateral equipment, and highly specialized real property installed equipment such as, but not limited to, compressors, blast booths, aging sanding and painting related equipment and hazardous waste reduction equipment at the Corrosion Repair Facilities (CRFs) located at I Marine Expeditionary Force, (I MEF), II MEF, and III MEF (Okinawa and Hawaii). 

Engineer Modification Kits (EMK) $3.777M: Continues to fund EMK for equipment armor installations, upgrades and safety concerns to prevent deterioration in Fleet readiness for Engineer Systems inventory consisting of over 47,000 end items associated to 120 TAMCNs.  Funding provides upgrades to mine plows; FSR support and Tech Manual (TM) updates for the Assault Breacher Vehicles (ABV); and Information Assurance (IA) support through Toughbook procurement and refresh.  Supports modifications and upgrades to fielded legacy as well as newly fielded systems and provides quick response capability for meeting Fleet Marine Force sustainment for safety engineering, readiness, Quality Deficiency Report analysis, and legacy system modifications.  Decrease of $3.699M from FY19 to FY20 reflects the Marine Corps decision to reprogram to higher priorities.

Marine Corps Family of Containers (MCFC) $1.213M: Funds equipment such as Joint Modular Intermodal Containers. The JMIC is a collapsible, durable, reusable, easy-to-handle, modular packaging container that can operate world-wide, carried by various modes of transportation, and is envisioned for future use as a compliment to Navy seabasing efforts for automatic loading, handling, and storage systems. The JMIC will enable Marines to fulfill their mission by giving the unit commander the flexibility to configure a mobile/deployable container as necessary to meet the specific mission of the unit. It provides the operating forces with a fully intermodal transport capability which lays flat when not in use. The JMIC also provides a more effective use of storage areas in particularly limited storage facilities. Funding is required to meet the Approved Acquisition Objective outlined in the Total Force Structure Management System. The increase in funding of $0.126M from FY19 to FY20 supports the plan to procure increased quantity of JMICs to meet AAO.

Family of Expeditionary Water Systems (FEWS) $5.071M (Active: $4.700M/Reserve: $0.371M): Funds will procure Platoon Water Purification System (PWPS). The increase in funding from FY19 to FY20 $0.808M supports procurement Platoon Water Purification System (PWPS) program of record.

FY 2021 Base Appropriation: $9.174M (Active: $8.798M/Reserve: $0.376M)

Corrosion Prevention and Control (CPAC) $0.913M: The consolidated CPAC program currently monitors the corrosion condition of 112,672 tactical ground and support equipment assets.  FY21 funding continues to procure equipment protective covers designed to reduce and/or eliminate the negative effects of corrosion on USMC ground tactical and support equipment and the replacement of aging covers that have exceeded their life expectancy.  The priority will be to provide equipment covers throughout the Operating Forces for equipment placed in an administrative staging program to mitigate the negative impacts of corrosion and decrease total ownership costs.  Procurement funding is also used for the fielding and replacement of various personal property/collateral equipment, and highly specialized real property installed equipment such as, but not limited to, compressors, blast booths, aging sanding and painting related equipment and hazardous waste reduction equipment at the Corrosion Repair Facilities (CRFs) located at I Marine Expeditionary Force, (I MEF), II MEF, and III MEF (Okinawa and Hawaii). The increase of funding of $0.018M from FY20 to FY21 supports the continual increasing cost to replace specialized CPAC equipment.

Engineer Modification Kits (EMK) $3.463M: Continues to fund EMK for equipment armor installations, upgrades and safety concerns to prevent deterioration in Fleet readiness for Engineer Systems inventory consisting of over 47,000 end items associated to 120 TAMCNs.  Supports modifications and upgrades to fielded legacy as well as newly fielded systems and provides quick response capability for meeting Fleet Marine Force sustainment for safety engineering, readiness, Quality Deficiency Report analysis, and legacy system modifications.  Decrease of $0.314M from FY20 to FY21 reflects completion of Light Weight Demolition Device (LWDD) ECP.

Marine Corps Family of Containers (MCFC) $1.248M: Funds equipment such as Joint Modular Intermodal Containers. The JMIC is a collapsible, durable, reusable, easy-to-handle, modular packaging container that can operate world-wide, carried by various modes of transportation, and is envisioned for future use as a compliment to Navy seabasing efforts for automatic loading, handling, and storage systems. The JMIC will enable Marines to fulfill their mission by giving the unit commander the flexibility to configure a mobile/deployable container as necessary to meet the specific mission of the unit. It provides the operating forces with a fully intermodal transport capability which lays flat when not in use. The JMIC also provides a more effective use of storage areas in particularly limited storage facilities. Funding is required to meet the Approved Acquisition Objective outlined in the Total Force Structure Management System.  The increase from the FY20 request to the FY21 request of $0.035M aligns to the procurement plan for JMIC.

Family of Expeditionary Water Systems (FEWS) $3.550M (Active: $3.174M/Reserve: $0.376M): Funds will procure Water Supply Support Components. The decrease in funding from FY20 to FY21 $1.521M reflects completion of various Water Supply Support Components and funding in this line item has been reprioritized while ensuring the Marine Corps continues to evolve toward a Force that is aligned with the National Defense Strategy

Name.@footnote: The FY21 funding decrease ($0.139M) from the FY20 request to the FY21 request aligns to the procurement plan for Joint Modular Intermodal Containers (JMIC).
